subtitle: Make sure you are both OK
description: Make sure you are both OK
title: Check-ups after birth
content:
Created by BabyCenter

It is good, and reassuring, to have health check-ups in the weeks after your baby is born, to make sure both you and your baby are OK. Remember, boys and girls need the same amount of check-ups.

Visit the health worker with your baby at least once during week 1 (ideally when he is 3 days old) and again when she is 6 weeks old. 

Take your baby to the clinic immediately if:

 - Her tummy is too cold or too hot
 - She develops yellow eyes, hands and feet within the first day of his life
 - She refuses to feed or sucks poorly
 - She will not stop crying or if her cry sounds unusual
 - She has a fit, is drowsy and not moving much, or has bluish skin or nails
 - She is wheezing, grunting, or breathing quickly 
 - She is vomiting after every feed for more than a day, or has a swollen tummy
 - The area around your baby's cord stump is red or smelly

These are signs that your baby is unwell, and needs treatment quickly.
